channel.title: Cross Device Tracking - Add warning to speakers similarly to microphones
channel.description:
Speakers are no different from microphones in the technical words because speakers can turn to microphone.
in whonix docs slightly covering that through turning speakers into microphone study https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Microphone#Eavesdropping_Risk)
Cross Device Tracking
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-device_tracking
DolphinAttack: Inaudible Voice Commands
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1708.09537.pdf
MOSQUITO:Covert Ultrasonic Transmissions between Two Air-Gapped Computers using Speaker-to-Speaker Communication
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1803.03422.pdf
Demonstration video:
https://invidious.snopyta.org/watch?v=ZD8CNxYe5dk
Explanation video by The Hated One:
https://invidious.snopyta.org/watch?v=j1FfVK6sj4I

item.title: Cross Device Tracking - Add warning to speakers similarly to microphones
item.dc:creator: TNT_BOM_BOM
item.description:
Speakers are no different from microphones in the technical words because speakers can turn to microphone.

in whonix docs slightly covering that through turning speakers into microphone study https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Microphone#Eavesdropping_Risk)

Cross Device Tracking

en.wikipedia.org

Cross-device tracking

Cross-device tracking refers to technology which enables the tracking of users across multiple devices such as smartphones, television sets, smart TVs, and personal computers. More specifically, cross-device tracking is a technique in which technology companies and advertisers deploy trackers, often in the form of unique identifiers, cookies, or even ultrasonic signals, to generate a profile of users across multiple devices, not simply one. For example, one such form of this tracking uses audio...
